Checking Out Files: stcmd co

Use stcmd co to check out files from an application repository (or vault) to your working folder using the command line. This command attempts to check out all the files (or all the specified files) from the specified location, regardless of their statuses. If you do not use  -o, this command pauses at each file with a Modified, Merge or Unknown status to let you know that the file will not be checked out. If you use -o, the application will force check out files of any status.

With the -merge option, you can merge files as part of the check-out process. Merging is not part of the check-in process.

 

Syntax

stcmd co -p "projectSpecifier" [-pwdfile "filePath"] [-cmp] [-csf] [-encrypt encryptionType] [-cfgl "labelName" | -cfgp "stateName" | -cfgd "asOfDate"] [-is] [-q] [-x] [-stop] [-rp "folderPath" | -fp "folderPath"] [-filter "fileStatus"] -merge [reportOption] [-hook "appName"] ] [-l | -u | -nel] [-ro | -rw] [-vl "labelName" | -vd "asOfDate" | -vn revisionNumber] [-f NCO] [-o | -i] [-ts] [-eol [on | off]] [-fs] [files...]

Example

The following example uses stcmd co to lock and check out .doc files from User Manual, a child of the root folder StarDraw (in the StarDraw view of the StarDraw project).

stcmd co -p "JMarsh:password@Orion:49201/StarDraw/StarDraw/User Manual" -l "*.doc"

The next example uses stcmd co to merge a readme file.

stcmd co -p "NTesla:@10.50.5.179:49201/WebDev/WebDev" -encrypt RC4 -fp "/export/home0/johnson/working" -merge "README"

 

For more information, see Using Common stcmd Options.
